ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: increased understanding of metal complex properties and spec methods
Understand the approach bio-inorganic chemists take to research.
I learned a lot about the inorganic chemistry of biological compounds (which I think is a much more appropriate name for the course)
This was a very interesting course and I feel I learned a lot of new things! Most of the material was not something I have heard before.
I barely learn anything from this course. This is the worst chemistry class I've ever taken.
I learned about bioinorganic chemistry, a big field I hadn't known much at all about.
Fundamentals of bioinorganic related instrumentation and assorted topics in bioinorganic chemisty.
I learned how to better approach the literature with a more comprehensive understanding of the material that will enable me to make more insightful observations in the future.

I learned what bio-inorganic chemistry is, how to think about inorganic chemistry more clearly, and how to come up with proposals (which I think was a really important primer for the rest of my scientific career).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: lectures a little difficult to follow

If this course was given in the first semester, the workload would be fine. However, for a second semester course, I found there were way too much expectations of students: weekly readings, quizzes & discussions, problem sets, a midterm, a final, two proposals. This is just too much if you also have to (and much rather would) spend time on your own research.

Although the attempt was made, there is an extreme focus on the isolated redox chemistry that the metalloenzymes do, with minimal to no discussion of how the enzymes work as a whole to do what it does. I was hoping the class would discuss how metalloenzymes function (i.e. substrate binding/conformational changes/origins of varying rates among proteins of the same family), and not how electrons move around a metal cofactor that just happens to be found in enzymes.It was obvious that the course was taught from a strict inorganic point of view, which is completely fine because I definitely learned a lot from the course, but taking even a small step back to look beyond the metal center of the enzyme would be nice.

I felt there was a bit more outside work than was necessary. The readings for ever class were excessive, especially when the assigned reading was an entire book chapter. It just isnt realistic for us to get done. The proposals were very useful to do, and I wish more classes discussed proposals.

The course was not well organized. I understand pat wanted to put lecture, discussion and presentation all in one course, but it made the whole course very disordered. I don't think the proposal presentations were helpful if we barely learn anything from the lecture.
I think it's pretty much ideal.
Detailed explanation of instrumentation was great! Proposal development was awesome. I would have liked to spend more class time on proposal development.
The strengths are that the course is very comprehensive, but it does demand a LOT of time compared to other graduate school courses.
I really liked the proposals even though I didn't like the idea of them at first
There might have been better ways to encourage class discussion, such as more time in our small groups.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the course was able to teach me a lot about inorganic chemistry and the spectroscopic techniques used in the field of inorganic chemistry.
Would recommend for a chemistry major looking to complement chemical biology and the MBB sequence
Yes! It was overall a great class and I would recommend this to anyone interested in inorganic or chembio.
No, it's a waste of time.
Yes, it was well structured, well taught, and relevant.
Would recommend to students who have an interest in bioinorganic and biochemistry
Yes, though the workload was greater, I felt like I got proportionally more out of the class compared to other courses.
yes. I learned a lot about bio-inorganic chemistry, and the expectations were clearly laid out which was really nice.
